Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Name the kingdom which first used elephants in wars?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Elephants were always a part of warfare in India. However, it were the rulers of Magadha who first employed elephants as a weapon of large-scale destruction. According to Plutarch, at the time of Alexander's invasion of India, the Nanda army comprised 6,000 war elephants which discouraged Alexander's men from further advancement.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The greatest king of the Pratihara dynasty was:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Mihira Bhoja I (836-885 CE) or Bhoja I is considered the greatest and most powerful ruler of the Pratihara dynasty. At its height, Bhoja's empire extended to Narmada River in the South, Sutlej River in the northwest, and up to Bengal in the east.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Who is considered founder of the Gupta Empire?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The history of the Gupta dynasty begins with its founding by Sri Gupta around 240 CE. He has been described as Maharaja in edicts. The most likely time for the reign of Sri Gupta is c. 240–280 CE. Chinese traveller Hiuen Tsang mentioned about Sri Gupta in his writings.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Kautilya's 'Arthashastra' mainly deals with:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Arthashastra is an ancient Indian treatise on statecraft, economic policy and military strategy, written by Kautilya. It is essentially a book of state and administrative system and deals with the art of government and politics.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: One of the following Indus Valley sites is in Pakistan:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Harappa is an archaeological site in Punjab, Pakistan. The site takes its name from a modern village located near the former course of the Ravi River. Harappa contains the ruins of a Bronze Age fortified city, which was part of the Cemetery H culture and the Indus Valley Civilization.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Who was the author of Telugu Work Amuktamalyada?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Krishnadevaraya (1509–30), the greatest emperor of the Vijayanagara Empire, composed Amuktamalyada. Considered a masterpiece in Telugu literature, the epic poem is believed to have been written and dedicated to Lord Venkateswara.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Who composed the Allahabad Pillar inscription?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Allahabad Pillar inscription or Allahabad Prasasti is one of the most important epigraphic evidences of the imperial Guptas. It was composed by Harisena, the court poet and minister of Samudragupta. It delineates a vivid description of the reign and conquests of Samudragupta.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Who built the famous Shiva Temple at Ellora?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Kailasa temple at Ellora, Maharashtra, was built in the 8th century by the Rashtrakuta king Krishna I as attested in Kannada inscriptions. This is one of the 34 temples and monasteries known collectively as the Ellora Caves. It is a megalith carved out of one single rock.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Which of the Kushana ruler patronized Buddhism?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Kanishka, the most famous Kushana ruler, patronized Buddhism. The Fourth Buddhist Council, in which Buddhism got split into two different schools—Hinayana and Mahayana—was held during his reign in Kashmir. He also patronized the Buddhist scholars—Vasumitra, Asvagosha and Nagarjuna.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Which of the following was the early capital of the Rashtrakutas?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: There is uncertainty about the location of the early capital of the Rashtrakutas. However, since most of the Rashtrakutas monuments are found at Ellora (Ilapura), it has been suggested that the early Rashtrakuta capital was located in the vicinity of the Ellora caves in the time of Dantidurga who was the founder and first ruler of the dynasty.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Whose army did Alexander, the Greek ruler confront on the banks of the river Jhelum?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Battle of the Hydaspes was fought by Alexander the Great in 326 BC against King Porus of the Paurava kingdom on the banks of the river Hydaspes (Jhelum) in the Punjab near Bhera. The battle resulted in a complete Macedonian victory and the annexation of the Punjab.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Find the odd one:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: There are four Vedas: the Rigveda, the Yajurveda, the Samaveda and the Atharvaveda. On the other hand, Vishnu Purana is a religious Hindu text and one of the eighteen Mahapuranas. It has been given the name Puranaratna.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Which Indian ruler fought the Kalinga War?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Kalinga War was fought between the Mauryan Emperor Ashoka and Raja Anantha Padmanabhan of Kalinga in 262–261 BC. It was the only major war Ashoka fought after his accession to throne. However, it is one of the major and bloodiest battles in world history. The bloodshed of this war is said to have prompted Ashoka to adopt Buddhism.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Name the Republic which was a confederacy of tribes in the fifth century BC:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Vajji or Vrijji was a confederacy in the 6th century BC. The rulers of Vajji were a confederacy of the eight clans (atthakula) of whom the Valls, the Licchavis, the Jnatrikas and the Videhas were the most important. It was one of the sixteen Mahajanapadas.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Which was the oldest University?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Nalanda was an ancient center of higher learning in Bihar which was a religious center of learning from the fifth or sixth century CE to 1197 CE. At its peak, the university attracted scholars and students from as far away as Tibet, China, Greece, and Persia. Nalanda was ransacked and destroyed by an army under Bakhtiyar Khilji in 1193.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Which one of the following tribal assemblies was not involved in the election of the tribal chief?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Several tribal assemblies, such as sabha, samiti, vidatha, and gana mentioned in the Rigveda exercised deliberative, military and religious functions. But from the political point of view important were the sabha and samiti. We have also some traces of the election of tribal chiefs by the tribal assembly called the samiti.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: During which of the following periods of Indian History did the Kshatriyas have a distinct identity?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Kshatriyas as the 'Khattiyas' of Buddhist literature had a distinct identity at the time of the Buddha, but later their actual identity becomes vague. The same is also true of the Vaishyas. Of the three castes, the Brahmin is the most easily identifiable as a concrete social group.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Chinese travellers visited India primarily because:
options: A) they were interested in Buddhism
B) they were invited by the Indian kings
C) they were interested to study Indian culture
D) they were interested to stay in India
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.answer: A) they were interested in Buddhism
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: After the spread of the Buddhist religion, Chinese travellers came to India in big numbers to collect religious books and to visit holy places of Buddhism. Notable among those travellers included I-tsing, Fa-Hien and Hiuen Tsang.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The term 'Upanishad' literally implies:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Upanishad means 'sitting down near', referring to the student sitting down near the teacher while receiving esoteric knowledge. Monier-Williams' Sanskrit Dictionary adds that, 'Upanishad means setting to rest ignorance by revealing the knowledge of the supreme spirit'.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The Sage who is said to have aryanized South India, was:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Sage Agastya, often considered the father of traditional Indian Medicine, is also associated with the Aryanization of South India. The Yadavas of South India were the first to be aryanized. Agastya compiled the first Tamil grammar called Agathiyam.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The origin of Indian music can be traced to which of the following Vedic Samhitas?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Organized Indian music owes its origin to the Samaveda which was a collection (samhita) of hymns and detached verses from other Vedas, meant for recital. These hymns were sung by Udgatar priests at sacrifices in which the Soma ritual drink was offered in libration to various deities.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Ashoka spread Buddhism all over India and Ceylon by:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: For the spread of Buddhism, Ashoka sent missionaries (dharma mahamatras) all over India and beyond. The missionaries sent by Ashoka to the other countries were well received by them and the conversions took place easily because of the influence and the personal power Ashoka exercised.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: In which Rock Edict Ashoka mentions about the causalities of Kalinga War and declares the renunciation of war?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Rock Edict XIII and Minor Rock Edict I states that the human sufferings and mass killings due to the Kalinga War prompted Ashoka to take Buddhist religion and to adopt the path of 'Dhamma Vijaya' (win through religion) and 'Ahimsa' (non-violence).

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The Earliest Settlements of Aryan tribes were at:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The region where the Aryans settled in India around 1500 BC was called Sapta Sindhu (Seven Rivers), also referred to as the Brahmavarta. They spread to Indo-Gangetic plains in the later Vedic Period and this region came to be known as Aryavarta (1000 BC to 600 BC).

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Pancha Siddhantika of Varahamihira deals with:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The most famous work by Varahamihira is the treatise on mathematical astronomy called the Pancha Siddhantika ('Five Astronomical Treatises'). It is dated 575 AD. It is a summary of five earlier astronomical systems, namely the Surya, Romaka, Paulisa, Vasistha and Paitamaha.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Which one of the following coins was issued in silver during the Gupta period?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The silver coins issued during the Gupta period were called 'Rupyaka'. These coins were based on Sakas of Ujjaini weighing 32–36 grains. However, according to Fa-Hien, cowries were the common means of exchange.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Lothal, the dockyard site of the Indus Valley Civilization, is situated in:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Lothal is located in the Bhal region of Gujarat. It is situated near the village of Saragwala in the Dholka Taluka of Ahmedabad district. The nearest cities are Dholka and Bagodara.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Buddha means:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The word 'Buddha' in Pali and Sanskrit means 'Enlightened one'. The word has become synonymous with Buddha Shakyamuni (Siddhartha Gautam) who is also known as Gautam Buddha.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Varahamihira was:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Varahamihira was an Indian astronomer, mathematician, and astrologer who lived in Ujjain in the 6th century AD. He is considered to be one of the nine jewels (Navaratnas) of the court of legendary ruler Yashodharman Vikramaditya of Malwa.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: During the reign of Bindusara there was unrest at:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: During the reign of Bindusara, Chandragupta Maurya's son and successor, there was unrest at Taxila in the north-western province of Sindh. He sent Ashoka (his son) to quell the uprising. Taxila was a highly volatile place because of the Indo-Greek presence and mismanagement of Governor Susima.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Name the Greek Ambassador at the Mauryan Court:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Megasthenes was a Greek ethnographer and explorer who served as an ambassador of Seleucus I of the Seleucid dynasty to Chandragupta Maurya. His 'Indica', throws light on the contemporary society, religious beliefs and social stratification.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Who was the contemporary South Indian ruler of Harshavardhana?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Harshavardhana (606 to 647 AD) and Pulakesin (610–642 AD) were contemporaries to each other. According to the Aihole inscription, Pulakesin of the Chalukyan dynasty defeated Harshavardhana of Kannauj on the banks of the Narmada.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Which one of the following is the most lasting contribution of the Rashtrakutas?
options: B) Pampa, Ponna, Ranna, the three writers of Kannada poetry and Kailasha Temple
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.answer: B) Pampa, Ponna, Ranna, the three writers of Kannada poetry and Kailasha Temple
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Kannada literature reached great heights under the Western Chalukyas and the Rashtrakutas who succeeded them. King Amoghavarsha I was himself one of the gems of Kannada. Adikavi Pampa, Sri Ponna and Ranna, called the 'three gems' of Kannada literature, found enthusiastic patronage from Rashtrakuta rulers. Similarly, the Kailasa Temple is a contribution of the Rashtrakutas.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Ravikirti, a Jain, who composed the Aihole Prashasti, was patronized by:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Ravikirti was the court poet of Chalukya King, Pulakesin II who reigned from 610 to 642 AD. He authored the Aihole inscription at Meguti Temple which describes the defeat of Harshavardhana by Pulakesin II and the shifting of the capital from Aihole to Badami.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The original founder of the Manuscripts and Editor of Kautilya's Arthashastra was:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: In 1905, R. Rama Shashtri discovered and published the Arthashastra, an ancient Indian treatise on statecraft. He transcribed, edited and published the Sanskrit edition in 1909. He proceeded to translate it into English, publishing it in 1915.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: From which among the following rulers has the Government of India borrowed and adopted its symbols?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The National Emblem of India is derived from the time of the Emperor Ashoka. It is a replica of the Lion of Sarnath, near Varanasi in Uttar Pradesh. The Lion Capital was erected by the Emperor Ashoka in 3rd century BC to mark the spot where Buddha first proclaimed his gospel of peace and emancipation.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: 6th century BC was an age of:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The 6th century BC was an age of religious ferment in the world. In India, it witnessed the birth of Buddhism and Jainism. It was in the same period that Heraclitus preached his new doctrines in the Greek island of Ionia; Zoroaster launched his protest against the prevailing religious superstitions in Iran and Confucius showed a new way of life in China.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Which of the following countries has asked India to return the famous 'Dancing Girl' statue from Mohenjodaro?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Sindh government of Pakistan in February 2014, requested Islamabad for asking India to return the famous statue of the Dancing Girl, which is in possession of the Indian authorities since 1946. The 10.8 cm bronze statue, made in 2500 BC, is on display at the National Museum in New Delhi.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Who is the founder of Jainism in India?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: According to Jain scriptures, Vardhaman Mahavira, the 24th and last Tirthankara founded Jainism as a faith in the 5th or 6th century BC. The religion derives its name from the jinas ('conquerors'), a title given to twenty-four great teachers (Tirthankara) through whom their faith was revealed.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Who compiled the tales of 'The Panchatantra'?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Panchatantra is attributed to Vishnu Sharma. It is an ancient Indian collection of inter-related animal fables in verse and prose arranged within a frame story. The original Sanskrit work, some scholars believe was composed around the 3rd century BC.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Ajanta Caves were built during period of:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Ajanta Caves in Aurangabad district of Maharashtra, are about 30 rock-cut Buddhist cave monuments which date from the 2nd century BCE to about 480 or 650 AD. Most of them were constructed during Gupta Period.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Which was the backbone of Indus Economy?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: As in most other contemporary civilizations, agriculture was the backbone of the Indus economy. The people made extensive use of the wooden plows. Barley and wheat were the main food crops. Agriculture sustained the rudimentary urban centers that emerged.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The author of Arthashastra was a contemporary of:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Arthashastra was authored by Kautilya, also known as Vishnugupta, who was a contemporary and Mentor of Chandragupta Maurya, founder of the Mauryan Empire. It is an ancient Indian treatise on statecraft, economic policy and military strategy, written in Sanskrit.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Which one of the following was the book written by Amoghvarsha the Rashtrakuta King?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: 'Kavirajamarga' (meaning 'Royal Path for Poets') was written by the famous Rashtrakuta King 'Nrupatunga' Amoghavarsha I. It is the earliest available writing on rhetoric, poetics and grammar in the Kannada language. It was written around 850 AD.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Who built the Kailasanatha Temple at Ellora?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Kailasa Temple was built by the Rashtrakuta king Krishna I in the 8th century AD. It is a megalith carved out of one single rock, one of the 34 monasteries and temples known collectively as the Ellora Caves. It is a remarkable example of Dravidian architecture.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The land measures of the Second Pandyan Empire were mentioned in:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Thalavaipuram copper plate brought out during 1018 and 1054 AD by the Pandyan kings, describes land system, giant waves, etc. For example, it mentions six qualifications for a Brahmin to get land as a gift from the king. Kasakudi plates and Uttaramerur inscription are related to the Pallava and Chola dynasties respectively.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Who was the greatest ruler of the Satavahanas?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Gautamiputra Satakarni (78–102 AD) is often acknowledged by historians as the greatest of the Satavahana rulers. He defeated the Yavanas, Sakas, and Pallavas and re-established the ancient glory of the Satavahanas. He performed two Ashwamedha sacrifices.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Who built the famous Vaikunta Perumal Temple at Kanchipuram?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Vaikunta Perumal Temple in Kanchipuram is believed to have been built by the Pallava king Nandi Varman II, with later contributions from Medieval Cholas and Vijayanagara kings. It is constructed in the Dravidian style of architecture.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The first to invade India were the:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: A majority of historians believe that the Aryans were the first to invade India in the later stages of the Indus Valley Civilization around 1700 BC. The Aryans came to India in bands and over several centuries in the 2nd millennium BC. Historians are divided on the issue of their original homeland.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Name the oldest Indian civilization:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Indus Valley Civilization was the oldest civilization to have flourished in the Indian subcontinent. Generally dated between 3000 BC to 1800 BC, it was one of three early civilizations of the Old World along with Ancient Egypt and Mesopotamia. It was a Bronze Age civilization.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The religion, which preached 'Desire is the cause for all sufferings', is:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Siddhartha or Gautam Buddha was born in 563 BC at Lumbini near Kapilvastu (Nepal). According to Buddhism the cause of suffering leading to endless rebirth is desire.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The Jaina literature is known as:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Jaina literature is known as Angas. The first attempts to systematise the preachings of Lord Mahavira, were made in the Pataliputra Council in the 4th century BC, but they were finally rearranged, redacted and committed to writing in the Valabhi Council in 512 AD under the presidentship of Devardhi Ksharnasramana.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Mention the centre of the Roman trade during the Sangam Age:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The important towns of Chera dynasty were Musiri, Tondi, Bandar and Vanji. Roman built a temple of Augustus at Musiri.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Which inscription mentions about the village administration under the Cholas?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: A tenth century inscription on a temple wall of the brahman village of Uttaramerur gives the details of village administration under Cholas.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Who among the following propounded the theory of zero?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Aryabhatta was an Indian astronomer and mathematician. He is credited with the invention of Algebra and the theory of zero. India's first satellite, 'Aryabhatta' was named after him.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The school of arts developed during the Kushan Period with the mixture of Indian and Greek style is known as:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Gandhara School of art shows Greek influence, therefore, it is known as Indo-Greek art. The important features of this school are: Buddha is shown as Roman and Greek gods, Moustache and beard are added to Buddha's face, The figures of this school follow a given ratio between the size of the face and rest of the body. During first and second century blue grey schist stone was used to make idols.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Where was the first Buddhist Council held?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The first Buddhist Council was held at Rajgir in 483 BC during the reign of Ajatasatru. It was presided by Mahakassapa.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The caves and rock-cut temples at Ellora are:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Ellora represents the epitome of Indian rock-cut architecture. The 34 'caves' are actually structures excavated out of the vertical face of the Charanandri hills. Buddhist, Hindu and Jain rock-cut temples and viharas and mathas were built between the 5th century and 10th century. The 12 Buddhist (caves 1–12), 17 Hindu (caves 13–29) and 5 Jain (caves 30–34) caves, built in proximity, demonstrate the religious harmony prevalent during this period of Indian history.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The Seven Pagodas of Mahabalipuram are a witness to the art patronized by the:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: 'Seven Pagodas' has served as a nickname for the south Indian city of Mahabalipuram, also called Mamallapuram, since the first European explorers reached it. Mahabalipuram's Shore Temple, built in the 8th century CE under the reign of Pallava king Narasimhavarman II, stands at the shore of the Bay of Bengal. Legend has it that six other temples once stood with it.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Name the clan that Buddha belonged to:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Shakya was an ancient tribe (jana-pada) of the Indian Subcontinent in the 1st millennium BCE. In Buddhist texts the Shakyas, the inhabitants of Shakya janapada, are mentioned as a Kshatriya clan of Gotama gotra. The most famous Shakya was Gautama Buddha, a member of the ruling Gautama clan of Lumbini, who is also known as Shakyamuni Buddha, 'sage of the Shakyas', due to his association with this ancient kingdom.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Who was the author of the Kadambari, a great romantic play?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Kadambari is a romantic novel in Sanskrit. It was substantially composed by Banabhatta in the first half of the 7th century, who did not survive to see it through completion. The novel was completed by Banabhatta's son Bhushanabhatta, according to the plan laid out by his late father. It is conventionally divided into Purvabhaga (earlier part) written by Banabhatta, and Uttarabhaga (latter part) by Bhushanabhatta.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: During which Gupta King's reign did the Chinese traveller Fahien visit India?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Chandragupta II The Great was one of the most powerful emperors of the Gupta empire in northern India. His rule spanned c. 380–413/415 CE, during which the Gupta Empire achieved its zenith, art, architecture, and sculpture flourished, and the cultural development of ancient India reached its climax. Fahien was the first of three great Chinese pilgrims who visited India from the fifth to the seventh centuries CE, in search of knowledge, manuscripts and relics. Fahien arrived during the reign of Chandragupta II and gave a general description of North India at that time.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: St. Thomas is said to have come to India to propagate Christianity during the reign of the:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: St. Thomas is traditionally believed to have sailed to India in 52 AD to spread the Christian faith among the Jews, the Jewish diaspora present in Kerala at the time. He is supposed to have landed at the ancient port of Muziris near Kodungalloor. Thomas landed in Cranganoor (Kodungallur, Muziris) and took part in the wedding of Cheraman Perumal and proceeded to the courts of Gondophorus in North India. Gundaphorus was indeed a historical figure and he belonged to the Parthian Dynasty from Takshashila (Taxila).

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The people of the Indus Valley Civilization usually built their houses of:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Indus Valley Civilization, marked by its remarkable level of urbanization despite being a Bronze Age culture, is noted for its cities built of brick, road-side drainage system, and multistoried houses. Houses were one or two stories high, made of baked brick, with flat roofs, and were just about identical. Each was built around a courtyard, with windows overlooking the courtyard. The outside walls had no windows. Each home had its own private drinking well and its own private bathroom.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Who started the Saka Era and when?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Most of what is known about Kanishka derives from Chinese sources, particularly Buddhist writings. When Kanishka came to the throne is uncertain. His accession has been estimated as occurring between his reign is believed to have lasted 23 years. The year 78 marks the beginning of the Saka era, a system of dating that Kanishka might have initiated.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The staple food of the Vedic Aryans was:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Vedic economy revolved around cow and dairy products which is clear from the references found in the Rigveda. The economy was primarily pastoral. The staple diet of the people was milk, ghee (clarified butter), vegetables, fruit and barley. On special occasions like a religious feast or the arrival of a guest, a more elaborate meal was organized.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: With which of the following centers of learning was Chanakya, the famous teacher of Chandragupta Maurya, associated?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Takshashila, (later corrupted as Taxila), was Chanakya's breeding ground of acquiring knowledge in the practical and theoretical aspect. He served there as a teacher also before becoming the chief advisor and mentor of Chandragupta Maurya. During the reign of Chandragupta's grandson Ashoka, Taxila became a great Buddhist centre of learning.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Ratha temples at Mahabalipuram were built in the reign of which Pallava ruler?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Pancha Rathas is an example of monolith Indian rock-cut architecture dating from the late 7th century, located at Mahabalipuram. The Pancha Rathas shrines were carved during the reign of King Mahendravarman-I and his son Narasimhavarman-I. The purpose of their construction is not known, structures are not completed.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Which one of the following Chola Kings conquered Ceylon (Singhal) first?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Rajaraja began his conquests by attacking the confederation between the rulers of the Pandya and Kerala kingdoms and of Ceylon. Rajendra Chola I, the son of Rajaraja, invaded the island in 1018 AD. As a result of the campaign, Rajendra captured the crown of the Sinhala king, his Queen and daughter. The Sinhala king Mahinda-V was taken prisoner and transported to the Chola country. The naval supremacy of the Cholas continued under the immediate successors of Rajendra.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Most of the Chola temples were dedicated to:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Great Living Chola Temples are important Hindu Kovils that were built during the 10th through 12th centuries CE in the south of India, and together have been designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The kovils are the Brihadeeswarar Temple at Thanjavur, Brihadeeswarar kovil at Gangaikonda Cholapuram and the Airavatesvarar Kovil at Darasuram. In all these temples, the chief deity who has been depicted and worshipped is Lord Shiva. The Cholas were followers of Saiva pantheon.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: In the Gupta period, the largest numbers of coins were issued in:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Coins minted in the Gupta Age were mostly made in gold. These coins consisted of the depiction of Indian deities and legends in Brahmi. Events like the Asvamedha Yagya and the accomplishments of the kings were also depicted on the coins.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The tax which the kings used to collect from the people in the Vedic period was called:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Vedic state derived its revenue from people's contribution, which was known as 'Bali'. It was a voluntary contribution given by the people to the king for protection and maintenance of law and order. This was different from regular taxation and was based on the principle of reciprocity between the ruler and the ruled.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Which metal was first used by the Vedic people?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Rigveda mentions such artisans as the carpenter, the chariot-maker, the weaver, the leather worker, the potter, etc. This indicates that they practiced all these crafts. The term, ayas used for copper or bronze shows that metal working was known. Gold was known as 'hiranya'.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Buddhism made an important impact by allowing two sections of society into its fold. They were:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Buddha was against caste. His religion was open to all, to sudras, women and even repentant criminals. The Buddhist scriptures were available to all men and women. Buddhism encouraged abolition of distinctions in society and strengthened the principle of social equality.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The language used to write source materials in ancient time was:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Pali is a Middle Indo-Aryan language (of Prakrit group) of the Indian subcontinent. It is best known as the language of many of the earliest extant Buddhist scriptures, as collected in the Pali Canon or Tipitaka, and as the liturgical language of Theravada Buddhism. T.W. Rhys Davids in his book Buddhist India, and Wilhelm Geiger in his book Pali Literature and Language, suggested that Pali may have originated as a form of lingua franca or common language of culture among people who used differing dialects in North India, used at the time of the Buddha and employed by him.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Name the capital of the Pallavas:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Pallavas ruled regions of northern Tamil Nadu and southern Andhra Pradesh between the second to the ninth century c.e. Kanchipuram served as the capital city of the Pallava Kingdom from the 4th to the 9th century. It is also known by its former names Kanchiampathi, Conjeevaram, and the nickname 'The City of Thousand Temples'. Kanchipuram was mentioned in the Mahabhasya, written by Patanjali in the 2nd century b.c.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The word 'Veda' means:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Vedas ('knowledge') are a large body of texts originating in ancient India. Composed in Vedic Sanskrit, the texts constitute the oldest layer of Sanskrit literature and the oldest scriptures of Hinduism. The Vedas are apauruveya ('not of human agency'). They are supposed to have been directly revealed, and thus are called sruti ('what is heard'), distinguishing them from other religious texts, which are called smriti ('what is remembered').

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Buddha preached his first sermon at:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Sarnath is the deer park where Gautama Buddha first taught the Dharma, and where the Buddhist Sangha came into existence through the enlightenment of Kondanna. Sarnath is located 13 kilometres north-east of Varanasi, in Uttar Pradesh.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Whose achievements are recorded in the Allahabad Pillar inscription?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Allahabad Stone Pillar Inscription of Samudragupta is writings in stone pillar during the term of King Samudragupta located in Allahabad which mentioned events during his tenure in and around his empire. It is one of the most important epigraphic evidences of the Imperial Guptas. Composed by Harisena, it delineates the reign of the Guptas in ancient India. Achievements of different rulers of the Gupta lineage are also mentioned in the Allahabad Pillar Inscription. Harisena was the court poet and minister of Samudragupta.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The essential feature of the Indus Valley Civilization was:
options: A) Worship of forces of nature
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Among all the Bronze Age cultures, the Indus Valley Civilization was the most urbanized. A sophisticated and technologically advanced urban culture is evident in the Indus Valley Civilization making them the first urban centres in the region. The quality of municipal town planning suggests the knowledge of urban planning and efficient municipal governments. By 2600 b.c.e., the early Harappan communities had been turned into large urban centres. Such urban centres include Harappa, Ganeriwala, Mohenjodaro in modern-day Pakistan, and Dholavira, Kalibangan, Rakhigarhi, Rupar, and Lothal in modern-day India.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: India's trade with the Roman Empire came to an end with the invasion of Rome by the:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Roman trade with India started around the beginning of the Common Era following the reign of Augustus and his conquest of Egypt. Following the Roman-Persian Wars Khosrow I of the Persian Sassanian Dynasty captured the areas under the Roman Byzantine Empire. The Arabs, led by 'Amr ibn al-'As, crossed into Egypt in late 639 or early 640 c.e. That advance marked the beginning of the Islamic conquest of Egypt and the fall of ports such as Alexandria, used to secure trade with India by the Greco Roman world since the Ptolemaic dynasty. The decline in trade saw Southern India turn to Southeast Asia for international trade, where it influenced the native culture to a greater degree than the impressions made on Rome. The Hunas invaded the Roman Empire under Attila the Hun in 454 c.e.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Most of the Chola temples were dedicated to:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Most of the Chola temples were dedicated to Shiva. The great living Chola temples are important Hindu kovils that were built during the 10th–12th centuries in the South India. In all these temples, the chief deity who has been depicted and worshipped is Lord Shiva.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: 'Bull' in Buddhism is associated with which event of Buddha's life?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The five great events in Buddha's life are represented by symbols as under: (a) Birth by Lotus and Bull, (b) Great Renunciation by Horse, (c) Nirvana by Bodhi Tree, (d) First Sermon by Dharmachakra or Wheel and (e) Parinirvana or death by the stupa.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Which of the following would be the most accurate description of the Mauryan Monarchy under Ashoka?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Despotism is a form of government in which a single entity rules with absolute power. However, in enlightened absolutism (also known as benevolent despotism), absolute monarchs used their authority to institute a number of reforms in the political systems and societies of their countries. During Ashoka's reign, the Mauryan Empire was indeed the first attempt in India to secure administrative centralization on an extended scale. Within its framework it united a number of people and tribes. The nature of the Mauryan government was enlightened despotism. The centralized monarchy became a paternal despotism under the able guidance of Ashoka.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The illustrious names of Aryabhatta and Varahamihira are associated with the age of the:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Gupta Empire was an ancient Indian empire which existed from approximately 320 to 550 c.e. and covered much of the Indian Subcontinent. Scholars of this period include Varahamihira and Aryabhatta, who is believed to be the first to come up with the concept of zero, postulated the theory that the Earth moves round the Sun, and studied solar and lunar eclipses. The most famous works of Aryabhatta are the Aryabhatya and the Aryasiddhanta. Varahamihira was an Indian astronomer, mathematician, and astrologer who lived in Ujjain. He is considered to be one of the nine jewels (Navaratnas) of the court of legendary ruler Vikramaditya (thought to be the Gupta emperor Chandragupta II Vikramaditya).

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Lothal is a site where dockyards of which of the following civilization were found?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Lothal is one of the most prominent cities of the ancient Indus Valley Civilization. Lothal's dock—the world's earliest known, connected the city to an ancient course of the Sabarmati river on the trade route between Harappan cities in Sindh and the peninsula of Saurashtra when the surrounding Kutch desert of today was a part of the Arabian Sea. It was a vital and thriving trade centre in ancient times, with its trade of beads, gems and valuable ornaments reaching the far corners of West Asia and Africa.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: 'Buddha' means:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The word Buddha is a title for the first awakened being in an era. 'Buddha' is also sometimes translated as 'The Enlightened One'. As Gautam fully comprehended the Four Noble Truths and as he arose from the slumbers of ignorance he is called a Buddha. Before his Enlightenment he was a bodhisattva which means one who is aspiring to attain Buddhahood. He was not born a Buddha, but became a Buddha by his own efforts. Every aspirant to Buddhahood passes through the bodhisattva period—a period comprising many lives over a vast period of time.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Where do you find the temple of Angkor Wat?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The temple of Angkor Wat is located in Angkor, Siem Reap Province, in Cambodia. It is the largest Hindu temple complex in the world. The temple was built by King Suryavarman II in the early 12th century in Yasodharapura, the capital of the Khmer Empire, as his state temple and eventual mausoleum. Breaking from the Shaivism tradition of previous kings, Angkor Wat was instead dedicated to Vishnu. As the best preserved temple at the site, it is the only one to have remained a significant religious centre since its foundation first Hindu, dedicated to the God Vishnu, then Buddhist. It has become a symbol of Cambodia, appearing on its national flag, and it is the country's prime attraction for visitors.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The capital of Pallavas was:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Located on the banks of river Vegavathy, Kanchipuram served as the capital city of the Pallava Kingdom during the 4th to 9th century a.d.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Who defeated Harshavardhana on the banks of Narmada?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Harsha's ambition of extending his power to the Deccan and Southern India were stopped by the great Chalukya Emperor of South India Pulakesin II, the Chalukya king of Vatapi in Northern Karnataka along the banks of river Narmada. Pulakesin defeated Harsha's army on the banks of the river Narmada in 620. A truce was agreed upon and the river Narmada was marked as the southern boundary of Harsha's kingdom.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: During whose reign did the Gandhara School of Art blossom?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Kushan period is considered the Golden Period of Gandhara. Peshawar Valley and Taxila are littered with ruins of stupas and monasteries of this period. Gandharan art flourished and produced some of the best pieces of Indian sculpture. Many monuments were created to commemorate the Jataka tales. The Gandhara civilization peaked during the reign of the great Kushan king Kanishka (128–151). The cities of Taxila (Takshasila) at Sirsukh and Peshawar were built.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Both Jainism and Buddhism had no faith in:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Jainism and Buddhism arose as a protest against the ritualism of the Hindu religion. Gautama Buddha and Vardhaman Mahavira both belonged to ruling families of Kshatriyas. Buddhism, as well as, Jainism had no faith in Vedic religion. Besides, both these heterodox sects had no faith in caste distinctions and opposed the caste-system vehemently.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The Gupta Era was founded by:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Chandragupta was a major king in the Gupta Empire around 320 c.e. and is generally considered the founder of the Gupta dynasty. As the ruler of the Gupta Empire, he is known for forging alliances with many powerful families in the Ganges region. The well known Gupta era which commenced on February 26, 320 a.d. is generally attributed to Chandragupta I. Hence, it is surmised that the Gupta era began on the occasion of the coronation of Chandragupta I.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The language from which the term 'India' is derived is:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The name India is derived from Indus, which originates from the Old Persian word Hindu. The latter term stems from the Sanskrit word Sindhu, which was the historical local appellation for the Indus River. The ancient Greeks referred to the Indians as Indoi which translates as 'the people of the Indus'.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Vaishakha Purnima has a great significance because it was on this day:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Vaishakha Purnima (Buddha Purnima or Vesak) is one of the most significant days in Buddhism as it commemorates three major events in Buddha's life: his birth, enlightenment (attaining Buddhahood), and Parinirvana (death). These three events are believed to have occurred on the same day of the year, making it the most sacred day for Buddhists worldwide.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Which was the only Indus site with an artificial brick dockyard?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Lothal was one of the most prominent cities of the ancient Indus Valley Civilization. Located in Bhal region of the modern state of Gujarat and dating from 2400 BCE, it was discovered in 1954. Lothal's dock—the world's earliest known, connected the city to an ancient course of the Sabarmati river on the trade route between Harappan cities in Sindh and the peninsula of Saurashtra when the surrounding Kutch desert of today was a part of the Arabian Sea.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Nalanda University was a great centre of learning, especially in:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Nalanda was an ancient centre of higher learning in Bihar, India. It was a Buddhist centre of learning from the fifth or sixth century CE to 1197 CE. Nalanda flourished between the reign of the Sakraditya and 1197 CE, supported by patronage from the Hindu Gupta rulers as well as Buddhist emperors like Harsha and later emperors from the Pala Empire.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The Rathas of Mahabalipuram was built during the reign of the:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The city of Mahabalipuram was largely developed by the Pallava king Narasimhavarman I in the 7th century AD. The mandapa or pavilions and the rathas or shrines shaped as temple chariots are hewn from the granite rock face, while the famed Shore Temple, erected half a century later, is built from dressed stone. The Pancha Rathas shrines were carved during the reign of King Mahendravarman I and his son Narasimhavarman.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: How was Burma (now Myanmar) known to ancient Indians?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Suvarnabhumi is a Sanskrit term meaning the 'Golden Land' or 'Land of Gold', coined by the ancient Indians which refers broadly to Southeast Asian region across Gulf of Bengal and Eastern Indian Ocean; Lower Burma, Lower Thailand, Lower Malay Peninsula, and Sumatra. Although it seems to cover vast region in Southeast Asia, it is generally accepted that the name Suvarnabhumi was first used to refer more specifically to Lower Burma.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: With whom is 'Junagarh Rock Inscription' associated?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Junagadh rock inscription, found in Junagadh, was carved under the orders of King Rudradaman, who had obtained the title of Mahakshatrapa. He was the grandson of the famous Mahakshatrapa Chastana and was a Saka ruler from the Western Kshatrapa dynasty. The inscription is a chronicle about the rebuilding of a dam named Urjayat around the lake Sudarshana.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Which of the following domesticated animals was absent in the terracottas of the Indus civilisation?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Indus Valley Civilization made sculptures mainly in stone, metal and terracotta. From the terracotta figurines, we come to know that the people of Harappa domesticated animals like oxen, buffaloes, pigs, goats and sheep. Camels and asses were used as means of transport. Dogs and cats were kept as pets. The humped bull was considered a great asset in the farming community.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Which among the following is the sacred book of the Buddhists?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Tripitaka is a traditional term used by various Buddhist sects to describe their various canons of scriptures. As the name suggests, a Tripitaka traditionally contains three 'baskets' of teachings: a Sutra Pitaka, a Vinaya Pitaka and an Abhidhamma Pitaka.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Prince Ellara conquered Sri Lanka in the second century BC. With which of the following dynasties of Dravida ruler was he associated?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Elara (235 BC–161 BC), also known as Manu Needhi Cholan was a Chola king from the Chola Kingdom, in present day South India, who ruled Sri Lanka from 205 BC to 161 BC from the ancient capital of Anuradhapura. Often referred to as 'the Just King'. The Tamil name Elalan means, the one who rules the Ellai (boundary).

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Harshavardhana organized his religious assembly at:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: After the Kannauj Assembly was concluded, Hiuen Tsang was making preparations to go to his home, but Harsha invited him to attend another Assembly at Prayag which he used to hold after every five years on the confluence of Ganga and Yamuna. Five such assemblies had already taken place and this was the sixth assembly in which Hiuen Tsang was invited. This ceremony was attended by the kings of 18 kingdoms and about 5,00,000 people including Sramanas, Heretics, Nigranthas, the poor, the orphans etc.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Which dynasty succeeded the Chalukyas in the Western India?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Chalukya dynasty was an Indian royal dynasty that ruled large parts of southern and central India between the 6th and the 12th centuries. In the western Deccan, the rise of the Rashtrakutas in the middle of the 8th century eclipsed the Chalukyas of Badami before being revived by their descendants, the Western Chalukyas, in the late 10th century.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Upto where did Chandragupta Maurya's empire extend in the northwest?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Prior to Chandragupta's consolidation of power, small regional kingdoms dominated the northwestern subcontinent, while the Nanda Dynasty dominated the middle and lower basin of the Ganges. After Chandragupta's conquests, the Maurya Empire extended from Bengal and Assam in the east, to Afghanistan and Balochistan, some part of the eastern and southeast Iran in the west, to Kashmir and Nepal in the north, and to the Deccan Plateau in the south. The vast empire extended from the Bay of Bengal in the east, to the Indus River in the west.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The greatest development in the Kushana period was in the field of:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Kushanas were great patrons of art. It was under the rule of the Kushans that principles were formed for making sculptural images, which continued to influence making of sculptures ever after. During this time, Buddha was first shown in human form (earlier he was represented by symbols like lotus and foot steps). Mathura and Gandhara were the two main centers of art during the time of the Kushanas.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Which was the only Indus city without a citadel?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Excavations at Chanhudaro have revealed three different cultural layers from lowest to the top being Indus culture, the Jhukar culture and the Jhangar culture. The site is especially important for providing evidences about different Harappan factories. These factories produced seals, toys and bone implements. It was the only Harappan city without a citadel.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Ashoka called the Third Buddhist Council at:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Third Buddhist council was convened in about 250 BCE at Ashokaramaya in Pataliputra, supposedly under the patronage of Emperor Ashoka. The traditional reason for convening the Third Buddhist Council is reported to have been to rid the Sangha of corruption and bogus monks who held heretical views. It was presided over by the Elder Moggaliputta Tissa and one thousand monks participated in the Council.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The tutor of Alexander, the Great was:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Aristotle was a Greek philosopher and polymath, a student of Plato and teacher of Alexander the Great. Together with Plato and Socrates (Plato's teacher), Aristotle is one of the most important founding figures in Western philosophy. Aristotle was invited by Philip II of Macedon to become the tutor to his son Alexander in 343 BC.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Which of the following literary works belongs to classical Sanskrit literature?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Meghadutam (cloud messenger) is a lyric poem written by Kalidasa, considered to be one of the greatest Sanskrit poets. In Sanskrit literature, the poetic conceit used in the Meghadutam spawned the genre of sandesha kavya or messenger poems, most of which are modeled on the Meghaduta (and are often written in the Meghaduta's mandakranta metre).

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Who propounded the 'Eightfold Path' for the end of misery of mankind?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Noble Eightfold Path is one of the principal teachings of the Buddha, who described it as the way leading to the cessation of suffering (dukkha) and the achievement of self-awakening. It is used to develop insight into the true nature of phenomena (or reality) and to eradicate greed, hatred, and delusion. The Noble Eightfold Path is the fourth of the Buddha's Four Noble Truths.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The number system 'Zero' was invented by:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The concept of zero as a number and not merely a symbol for separation is attributed to India, where by the 9th century AD, practical calculations were carried out using zero, which was treated like any other number. Around 500 AD, Aryabhatta, an Indian mathematician, devised a numbers system and the symbol he used for the number zero was also the number used to represent an unknown element (x).

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: 'Charak' was the famous court physician of:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Charaka was one of the principal contributors to the ancient art and science of Ayurveda, a system of medicine and lifestyle developed in Ancient India. He is referred to as the Father of Medicine. The French orientalist Sylvan Levi discovered in the Chinese translation of the Buddhist Tripitaka, a person named Charaka who was a court physician to the Indo-Scythian king Kanishka, who in all probability reigned in the second century AD.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Where has the world's monolithic statue of Buddhism been installed?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Buddhas of Bamiyan were two 6th century monumental statues of standing Buddha carved into the side of a cliff in the Bamiyan Valley in the Hazarajat region of central Afghanistan. They were dynamited and destroyed in March 2001 by the Taliban, on orders from leader Mullah Mohammed Omar, after the Taliban government declared that they were idols.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The Harappan Civilization was discovered in the year:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: In 1872–75 Alexander Cunningham published the first Harappan seal (with an erroneous identification as Brahmi letters). It was half a century later, in 1912, that more Harappan seals were discovered by J. Fleet, prompting an excavation campaign under Sir John Hubert Marshall in 1921–22 and resulting in the discovery of the civilization at Harappa and at Mohenjodaro.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The title 'Indian Napoleon' has been attached to:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Samudragupta (335–375 AD) of the Gupta dynasty is known as the Napoleon of India. Historian A.V. Smith called him so because of his great military conquests known from the 'Prayag Prashasti' written by his courtier and poet Harisena, who also describes him as the hero of a hundred battles.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The 'Ajivikas' were a:
options: A) Sect contemporary to the Buddha
B) Breakaway branch of the Buddhists
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.answer: A) Sect contemporary to the Buddha
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Ajivika ('living' in Sanskrit) was a system of ancient Indian philosophy and an ascetic movement of the Mahajanapada period in the Indian subcontinent. Ajivika was primarily a heterodox Hindu (Nastika) or atheistic system. One of their prominent leaders was Makkhali Gosala. Ajivikas are thought to be contemporaneous to other early Hindu nastika philosophical schools of thought, such as Charvaka, Jainism and Buddhism.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The organic relationship between the ancient cultures of the Indus Valley and Hinduism of today is proved by the worship of:
options: A) Pashupati, Indra and the Mother Goddess
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: There has been evidence that the people of the Indus Valley Civilization believed in some form of animal and nature worship. The figure of deities on the seals indicates that they worshipped gods and goddesses in the human form. The Divine Mother appears to have been an important goddess, due to the countless terracotta statues of her that were found. What is most interesting is the existence of a male god which has been identified as a proto-type of Lord Shiva.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The Saka era commencing from AD 78, was founded by:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Saka era commencing from 78 AD was founded by Kanishka.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Gandhara School of Art came into existence in:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Gandhara school of art is mainly related to Mahayana Buddhism which encouraged image worship. The Kushan kings, particularly Kanishka, encouraged the Gandhara artists. The Gandhara sculptures have been found in the ruins of Taxila and in various ancient sites in Afghanistan and in West Pakistan. They consist mostly of the images of the Buddha and relief sculptures presenting scenes from Buddhist texts.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Out of the following remains excavated in Indus Valley, which one indicates the commercial and economic development?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The seals of the Indus Valley Civilization have been one of the major sources for information about the period. Apart from giving plethora of information about the social and religious life of the period, they give insight into the economic activities. Trade amongst the civilizations is suggested by the finding of hundreds of small seals, supposedly produced by the Indus peoples, at the excavation sites of ancient Mesopotamian cities.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Who, according to the Buddhists, is believed to be the next incarnation of Gautam Buddha?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Maitreya is foretold as a future Buddha of this world in Buddhist eschatology. In some Buddhist literature, such as the Amitabha Sutra and the Lotus Sutra, he or she is referred to as Ajita Bodhisattva. Maitreya is a bodhisattva who in the Buddhist tradition is to appear on Earth, achieve complete enlightenment, and teach the pure dharma.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Who among the following were contemporaries of Kanishka?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The eminent Buddhist writers Nagarjuna, Asvaghosha, Parsva and Vasumitra flourished at the court of Kanishka. Nagarjuna was the great exponent of Mahayana doctrine and Asvaghosha, a multifaceted personality, was known as a poet, musician, scholar and zealous Buddhist monk. Vasumitra presided over the fourth Buddhist Council.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Which rulers built the Ellora Temples?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The only definite inscriptional evidence is that of Rashtrakuta Dantidurga (c. 753–57 AD). The majority of the Brahmanical establishments and the remaining Buddhist ones can be attributed to the Rashtrakuta times which indicate the religious tolerance of the contemporary period.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Who amongst the following also had the name 'Devanama Piyadassi'?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Edicts of Ashoka are a collection of 33 inscriptions on the Pillars of Ashoka, as well as boulders and cave walls, made by the Emperor Ashoka of the Mauryan dynasty during his reign from 269 BCE to 231 BCE. In these inscriptions, Ashoka refers to himself as 'Beloved of the Gods' and 'King Priyadarshi'. The identification of King Priyadarshi with Ashoka was confirmed by an inscription discovered in 1915.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The subject matter of Ajanta Paintings pertains to:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Ajanta Caves are the treasure house of delicate paintings that portray scenes from Jataka tales and from the life of Lord Buddha. Celebrated for its archaic wonder and laced with the series of carved artistry, Ajanta Cave paintings echo the quality of Indian creativity in perhaps the subtlest ways.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Which of the following Craftsmanship was not practiced by the Aryans?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Iron was a metal unknown to the Aryans during the early Vedic age. The advent of iron is generally associated with the late or post-Vedic ages. So blacksmith did not exist during this period.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Mohammed Bin Qasim conquered Sindh in the year:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Arab conquest of Sindh by Muhammad Bin Qasim in 712 AD gave the Muslims a firm foothold on the sub-continent. Qasim's conquest of Sindh and Punjab laid the foundations of Islamic rule in the Indian subcontinent.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The words 'Satyameva Jayate' in the State Emblem of India were taken from:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: 'Satyameva Jayate' (Truth Alone Triumphs) is a mantra from the ancient Indian scripture Mundaka Upanishad. Upon independence of India, it was adopted as the national motto of India. It is inscribed in Devanagari script at the base of the national emblem.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The earliest city discovered in India was:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The ruins of Harappa were first described in 1842 by Charles Masson in his Narrative of Various Journeys in Balochistan, Afghanistan, and the Punjab, where locals talked of an ancient city extending 'thirteen cosses' (about 25 miles), but no archaeological interest would attach to this for nearly a century. In 1856, General Alexander Cunningham later director general of the archaeological survey of northern India, visited Harappa.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The famous rock-cut temple Kailasa is at:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Kailashnath Temple is a famous temple, one of the 34 monasteries and temples, extending over more than 2 km, that were dug side by side in the wall of a high basalt cliff in the complex located at Ellora, Maharashtra, India. Of these 34 monasteries and temples, the Kailasa (cave 16) is a remarkable example of Dravidian architecture on account of its striking proportion; elaborate workmanship architectural content and sculptural ornamentation of rock-cut architecture.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Epigraphy means:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Epigraphy is the study of inscriptions on rocks, pillars, temple walls, copper plates and other writing material. It is the study of inscriptions or epigraphs as writing; it is the science of identifying graphemes, clarifying their meanings, classifying their uses according to dates and cultural contexts, and drawing conclusions about the writing and the writers.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Who is hailed as the 'God of Medicine' by the practitioners of Ayurveda?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Dhanvantari is an Avatar of Vishnu from the Hindu tradition. He appears in the Vedas and Puranas as the physician of the gods (devas), and the god of Ayurvedic medicine. It is common practice in Hinduism for worshipers to pray to Dhanvantari seeking his blessings for sound health for themselves and/or others. Dhanvantari is depicted as Vishnu with four hands, holding medical herbs in one hand and a pot containing rejuvenating nectar called amrita in another.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: What is the first sermon of Buddha called?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The first sermon Buddha gave to the five monks was called the Dhammacakkappavattana Sutta. It is also called the Setting in Motion of the Wheel of Dharma.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Buddha, Dhamma and Sangha together are known as:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Three Jewels (triratna) are the three things that Buddhists take refuge in, and look toward for guidance, in the process known as taking refuge. The three jewels are: Buddha, Dhamma and Sangha.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Who was called Lichchavi Dauhitra?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Chandragupta I was known as ‘Lichchavi Dauhitra’. His marriage with the Lichchavi Princess Kumaradevi was one of the significant events in the Gupta rule. The importance of this marriage can be known further from Samudragupta’s Allahabad inscription in which he has described himself as ‘Lichchhavis Dauhitra’ or daughter’s son of the Lichchavis.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Mahavira’s first disciple was: [SSC Constable (GD) Exam. 2013]
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Jamali, who was husband of Anonja Priyadarshini, was the first disciple of Mahavira. He was Mahavira’s son-in-law.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Vardhman Mahavir is also known as: [SSC Constable (GD) Exam. 2013]
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Vardhamana Mahavira was also known as ‘Jina’ which literally means the ‘conqueror’. Jina refers to the one who has conquered love and hate, pleasure and pain, attachment and aversion, and has there by freed ‘his’ soul from the karmas obscuring knowledge, perception, truth, and ability. It was from this word that Jainism was derived.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Which one of the following is not included in the Eight-fold Path’ of Buddhism? [SSC Constable (GD) Exam. 2013]
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Noble Eight-fold Path is one of the principal teachings of the Buddha, who described it as the way leading to the cessation of suffering (dukkha) and the achievement of self-awakening. The path comprises right view, right aspiration, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right concentration.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Which of the following dynasty succeeded the Maurya’s? [SSC Constable (GD) Exam. 2013]
The Buddhist monk who spread Buddhism in Tibet was:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The most important event in the history of Tibetan Buddhism was the arrival of sage Padmasambhava in the 8th century. Padmasambhava translated numerous Buddhist texts into Tibetan language and combined tantric Buddhism with the local Bon religion to create what is today widely known as the Tibetan Buddhism.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: King Kharvelawas the greatest ruler of the Chedi Dynasty of:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Kharvela was the third and greatest emperor of the Chedi dynasty of Kalinga (present-day Odisha). The main source of information about Kharavela is his famous Hanthigumpha inscription. During his reign, the Chedi dynasty ascended to eminence, which had been subdued since the devastating war with Ashoka.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Pulakesin II was the greatest ruler of the:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Pulakesin II (610–642 a.d.) was the most famous ruler of  the Chalukya dynasty. In his reign the  Chalukyas of Badami saw their kingdom extend over most of the Deccan.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The Uttaramerur inscription provides information on the administration of the:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: An inscription of the 8th century a.d. at Uttaramerur temple describes the constitution of the local council, eligibility and disqualifications for the candidates, the method selection, their duties and delimits their power in Chola dynasty.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Match the following:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Chalukyas : Vatapi (Badami); Hoysalas : Dwarasamudra; Rashtrakutas : Malkhed; and Kakatiyas: Warangal.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Which one of the following is the principal source of information on Ashoka’s campaign against Kalinga?
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Sunga Empire was an ancient Indian dynasty from Magadha that controlled vast areas of the Indian Subcontinent from around 187 to 78 b.c.e. The dynasty was established by Pusyamitra Sunga, after the fall of the Maurya Empire.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The Gandhara art flourished under:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Gandhara style flourished and achieved its peak during the Kushan period, from the 1st to the 5th centuries. It declined and suffered destruction after invasion of the White Huns in the 5th century.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Which one of the following inscriptions relate to the Chalukya king, Pulakesin II? [SSC (10+2) Level DEO & LDC Exam. 2013]
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Aihole inscription were written by the Ravikirti, poet of Chalukya King, Pulakesin II who reigned from 610 to 642 c.e. This inscription gives information about the conquests of Pulakesin, especially how he defeated Harshavardhana.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Which dynasty immediately succeeded the Maurya dynasty and ruled Magadha Kingdom? [SSC (10+2) Level DEO & LDC Exam. 2013]
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Sunga Dynasty, established by Pusyamitra Sunga, after the fall of the Maurya Empire. The last Mauryan emperor Brihadratha was assassinated by the then commander-in-chief of the Mauryan armed.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The capital of the ancient Chola kingdom was: [SSC (10+2) Level DEO & LDC Exam. 2013]
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Early Cholas of the pre and post Sangam period (300 b.c.e.–200 c.e.) were one of the three main kingdoms of the ancient Tamil country. Uraiyur, now Tiruchchirappalli was the ancient capital of the Chola Dynasty.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The script of the Indus Valley Civilization is: [SSC (10+2) Level DEO & LDC Exam. 2013]
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Although these seals and samples of Indus writing have been floating around the scholastic world for close to 70 years, little progress has been made on deciphering this elegant script. The Indus script is an un-deciphered script.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Worship of Mother Goddess was associated with:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: In view of the large number of figurines found in the Indus valley, some scholars believe that the Harappan people worshipped a Mother goddess symbolizing fertility, a common practice among rural Hindus even today.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Alexander and Porus fought a battle at:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The Battle of the Hydaspes River was fought by Alexander the Great in 326 b.c. against King Porus of the Hindu Paurava kingdom on the banks of the Hydaspes River (Jhelum River) in the Punjab near Bhera in what is now modern-day Pakistan. The battle resulted in a complete Macednian victory and the annexation of the Punjab, which lay beyond the confines of the defeated Persian Empire, into the Alexandrian Empire. The battle is historically significant for opening up India for Greek political (Seleucid Empire, Indo-Greeks) and cultural influence (Greco-Buddhist art) which was to continue for many centuries.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Identify the Buddhist Literature from the following:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Tripitaka is a traditional term used by various Buddhist sects to describe their various canons of scriptures. As the name suggests, a Tripitaka traditionally contains three ‘baskets’ of teachings: a Sutra Pitaka, a Vinaya Pitaka and an Abhidharma Pitaka. Tripitaka is the three main categories of texts that make up the Buddhist canon.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: Seleucus Nicator was defeated by:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Seleucus I Nicator was a leading officer of Alexander the Great’s League of Corinth and one of the Diadochi. In the Wars of the Diadochi that took place after Alexander’s death, Seleucus established the Seleucid dynasty and the Seleucid Empire. He was defeated by the emperor of India, Chandragupta Maurya and accepted a matrimony alliance for 500 elephants after ceding the territories considered as part of India.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The striking feature of the Indus Valley Civilization was:
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: The most characteristic feature of the Harappan Civilization was its urbanization. The cities show evidence of an advanced sense of planning and organization. The town was extremely well planned. The street ran straight and at right angles to each other following the grid system. The rectangular town planning was unique to the Harappans and was not known in Mesopotamia or Egypt. The streets were very wide and the houses built of burnt bricks lined both sides of the street. In Egypt and Mesopotamia dried or baked bricks were used.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: After Alexander’s death the Eastern part of his empire came under.
Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.explanation: Seleucus I was a leading officer of Alexander the Greatest League of Corinth and one of the Diadochi. In the Wars of the Diadochi that took place after Alexander’s death, Seleucus established the Seleucid dynasty and the Seleucid Empire. His kingdom would be one of the last holdouts of Alexander’s former empire to Roman rule. They were only outlived by the Ptolemaic Kingdom in Egypt by roughly 34 years.

Ancient & Medieval India–Religion & Cult.question: The early Buddhist scriptures were composed in:
